content: The "Independent Safety Board Act Amendments of 1994" authorizes appropriations for fiscal years 1994-1996. It also amends the definition of public aircraft in title 49 of the United States Code. The "Independent Safety Board Act Amendments of 1994" authorizes appropriations for fiscal years 1994-1996 and amends the definition of public aircraft in title 49 of the United States Code to include transporting crewmembers or persons for governmental functions or by the Armed Forces or intelligence agencies. An aircraft can be considered a public aircraft for the purposes of this part if it is operated by a unit of government in response to a significant threat, and no private operator is available. The Administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration has the authority to grant exemptions. The Administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration may grant exemptions to government units from certain requirements to prevent economic burden, provided their aviation safety program is effective. The Board has investigative authority over accidents involving public aircraft as defined by section 40102(a)(37) of title 49, United States Code. They have the same duties and powers for public aircraft accidents as for civil aircraft accidents. The amendments made by subsections (a) and (c) shall take effect on the 180th day following the date of the enactment of this Act. The United States releases reservations, restrictions, conditions, and limitations on certain real property in Rapides Parish, Louisiana. Esler Field in Rapides Parish, Louisiana, was conveyed to the Parish by the United States in 1958 with certain enforceable reservations. The United States retains the right to reenter or use the property for national defense purposes during war or national emergencies without charge. This release does not apply to specific conditions related to the airport's use by the Louisiana National Guard and transient military aircraft during maneuvers. The release of Esler Field in Rapides Parish, Louisiana, by the United States in 1958 includes reservations for national defense purposes during war or emergencies without charge. The section also clarifies that the release does not affect the ownership of mineral resources on the property. Additionally, the Federal Aviation Administration has specific agreements with the Rapides Parish Airport Authority regarding grant agreements and terms of use. The agreement in Rapides Parish, Louisiana, for the use, lease, sale, or disposal of real property must be finalized within 180 days of the enactment of the Act. This section will take effect 180 days after the Act's enactment.
